Using library modules for applications such as graphics, sound, GUI, database, Web, and network programming. Language features beyond those in I&C SCI 31 are introduced as needed.
I&C SCI 32.prerequisites: I&C SCI 31. I&C SCI 31 with a grade of C or better
I&C SCI 32.restriction: : School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI H32.title: Python Programming and Libraries (Accelerated)
I&C SCI H32.description: Introduces Python syntax and semantics for fundamental programming concepts.  Constructing programs for varied problems and environments. Using library modules for applications such as graphics, sound, GUI, database, Web, and network programming. Accelerated course for students with previous programming background.
I&C SCI H32.prerequisites: AP Computer Science A. AP Computer Science A with a minimum score of 3. Placement via a transfer course in computer programming or equivalent experience may also be accepted upon review.
I&C SCI H32.restriction: : Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 33.title: Intermediate Programming
I&C SCI 33.description: Intermediate-level language features and programming concepts for larger, more complex, higher-quality software. Functional programming, name spaces, modules, class protocols, inheritance, iterators, generators, operator overloading, reflection. Analysis of time and space efficiency.
I&C SCI 33.prerequisites: I&C SCI 32 or CSE 42 or I&C SCI 32A. I&C SCI 32 with a grade of C or better. CSE 42 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 32A with a grade of C or better
I&C SCI 33.restriction: : School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 45C.title: Programming in C/C++ as a Second Language
I&C SCI 45C.description: An introduction to the lexical, syntactic, semantic, and pragmatic characteristics of the C/C++ languages for experienced programmers. Emphasis on object-oriented programming, using standard libraries, and programming with manual garbage collection.
I&C SCI 45C.prerequisites: I&C SCI 33 or CSE 43 or EECS 40. I&C SCI 33 with a grade of C or better. CSE 43 with a grade of C or better. EECS 40 with a grade of C or better
I&C SCI 45C.restriction: : School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 45J.title: Programming in Java as a Second Language
I&C SCI 45J.description: An introduction to the lexical, syntactic, semantic, and pragmatic characteristics of the Java language for experienced programmers. Emphasis on object-oriented programming, using standard libraries, and programming with automatic garbage collection.
I&C SCI 45J.prerequisites: I&C SCI 33 or CSE 43. I&C SCI 33 with a grade of C or better. CSE 43 with a grade of C or better
I&C SCI 45J.restriction: : School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. I&C SCI 45J may not be taken for credit after I&C SCI 22, I&C SCI 23, or CSE 23.

I&C SCI 46.title: Data Structure Implementation and Analysis
I&C SCI 46.description: Focuses on implementation and mathematical analysis of fundamental data structures and algorithms. Covers storage allocation and memory management techniques.
I&C SCI 46.prerequisites: I&C SCI 33 and I&C SCI 45C. I&C SCI 33 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 45C with a grade of C or better
I&C SCI 46.restriction: : Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 51.title: Introductory Computer Organization
I&C SCI 51.description: Multilevel view, design, and operation of computer system components. Machine-level data and instruction representation. Instruction sets and addressing modes. Memory organization. Laboratory work using low-level programming languages.
I&C SCI 51.restriction: : School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 53.title: Principles in System Design
I&C SCI 53.description: Introduces basic principles of system software: operating systems, compilers, and networking. Exposure to the following topics through theoretical and practical programming experiences: linking and loading, process and memory management, concurrency and synchronization, network communication, programming for performance, etc.
I&C SCI 53.prerequisites: I&C SCI 46 and I&C SCI 51. I&C SCI 46 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 51 with a grade of C or better
I&C SCI 53.restriction: : School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 60.title: Games and Society
I&C SCI 60.description: The study and critical analysis of computer games as art objects, cultural artifacts, gateways to virtual worlds, educational aids, and tools for persuasion and social change. Emphasis on understanding games in their historical and cultural context.
I&C SCI 60.restriction: : Computer Game Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors have second right of consideration.

I&C SCI 61.title: Game Design Fundamentals
I&C SCI 61.description: Explore the fundamentals of game design through the design and play of simple analog game systems. Students explore the principles and usage of game design elements through hands-on projects emphasizing iteration and playtesting in a creative game design community.
I&C SCI 61.restriction: : Computer Game Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors have second right of consideration

I&C SCI 62.title: Game Technologies and Interactive Media
I&C SCI 62.description: Technologies for interactive media and game design. Web-based software systems, virtual world platforms, and game engines. Emphasis is on conceptual and architectural aspects of these technologies.

I&C SCI 80.title: Special Topics in Information and Computer Science
I&C SCI 80.description: Studies in selected areas of information and computer sciences. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

I&C SCI 90.title: New Students Seminar
I&C SCI 90.description: Introduces students to the Donald Bren School of Information and Computer Sciences. Focuses on advising students making the transition to UCI, community building, and mostly surveying the technical areas within departments in ICS, via talks by faculty on their research.
I&C SCI 90.restriction: : School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 139W.title: Critical Writing on Information Technology
I&C SCI 139W.description: Study and practice of critical writing and oral communication as it applies to information technology. Each student writes assignments of varying lengths, totaling at least 4,000 words.
I&C SCI 139W.prerequisites: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
I&C SCI 139W.restriction: : Upper-division students only. School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 161.title: Game Engine Lab
I&C SCI 161.description: The use of an open source game or graphics engine in the design and implementation of a computer game. Principles of game engine design. Students work on teams to design, implement, and evaluate new computer games based on an engine.
I&C SCI 161.prerequisites: I&C SCI 45C or GDIM 32 or I&C SCI 167
I&C SCI 161.restriction: : School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 162.title: Modeling and World Building
I&C SCI 162.description: Use of 3D modeling software and related tools to design and create animated, textured models, and expansive virtual worlds incorporating objects, scenes, and venues for activity within game worlds and online environments.
I&C SCI 162.restriction: : School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 163.title: Mobile and Ubiquitous Games
I&C SCI 163.description: Design and technology of mobile games, including mixed reality gaming, urban games, and locative media. Case studies of significant systems. Uses and limitations of location-based technologies. Infrastructures and their relationships to gameplay and design.
I&C SCI 163.prerequisites: (I&C SCI 61 or GDIM 25) and (GDIM 31 or I&C SCI 10 or I&C SCI 31 or I&C SCI 32A)

I&C SCI 166.title: Game Design
I&C SCI 166.description: Game design takes into consideration psychology, narrative, platform features and limitations, marketing, computer science capabilities, human-computer interface principles, industry trends, aesthetic judgment, and other factors. Students focus on video game design through lectures, readings, presentations, implementation, and play testing.
I&C SCI 166.restriction: : Computer Game Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors have second consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 167.title: Multiplayer Game Systems
I&C SCI 167.description: Foundations and technologies that enable multiuser, networked, and persistent virtual environments. Emphasis on database design and management, network protocols, and concurrency control to accommodate large numbers of simultaneous users.
I&C SCI 167.restriction: : School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Game Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 168.title: Multiplayer Game Project
I&C SCI 168.description: Design and develop a multiplayer game using Unity or similar engine, with a focus on learning to work in a development team, writing design documents, working with platform features and limitations, developing engaging mechanics, playtesting, and post-mortems.
I&C SCI 168.prerequisites: (GDIM 27 or I&C SCI 166) and (GDIM 33 or I&C SCI 161) and (GDIM 61 or I&C SCI 62). GDIM 27 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 166 with a grade of C or better. GDIM 33 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 161 with a grade of C or better. GDIM 61 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 62 with a grade of C or better
I&C SCI 168.restriction: : Computer Game Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors have second consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 169A.title: Capstone Game Project I
I&C SCI 169A.description: Students work in teams to design and implement a unique game or interactive experience. Emphasis on sound, art, and level design, building a community, production values, full utilization of hardware and software platform, and current industry trends.
I&C SCI 169A.prerequisites: GDIM 27 or GDIM 61 or I&C SCI 62 or I&C SCI 166. GDIM 27 with a grade of C or better. GDIM 61 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 62 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 166 with a grade of C or better
I&C SCI 169A.restriction: : Seniors only. Computer Game Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors given second right of consideration.

I&C SCI 169B.title: Capstone Game Project II
I&C SCI 169B.description: Students continue work in teams to design and implement a unique game or interactive experience. Emphasis on sound, art, and level design, building a community, production values, full utilization of hardware and software platform, and current industry trends.
I&C SCI 169B.prerequisites: GDIM 167A or I&C SCI 169A. GDIM 167A with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 169A with a grade of C or better. In Progress grade for GDIM 167A or I&C SCI 169A also accepted.
I&C SCI 169B.restriction: : Seniors only. Computer Game Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors given second right of consideration.

I&C SCI 192.title: Industrial or Public Sector Field Study
I&C SCI 192.description: Students participate in an off-campus, supervised internship for a minimum of 60 hours. Students apply classroom knowledge through internship projects in the private sector or nonprofit agencies.
I&C SCI 192.restriction: : School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 193.title: Tutoring in ICS
I&C SCI 193.description: Principles and practice of providing technical assistance to novice learners in information and computer sciences.
I&C SCI 193.restriction: : ICS Peer Tutoring Program students only.

I&C SCI H197.title: Honors Seminar
I&C SCI H197.description: An overview of computer science and selected recent trends in research. Students attend talks on current faculty research, with opportunities for discussion.
I&C SCI H197.restriction: : Campuswide Honors Collegium students only. Bren School of ICS Honors students only.

I&C SCI 398A.title: Teaching Assistant Training Seminar
I&C SCI 398A.description: Theories, methods, and resources for teaching computer science at the university level, particularly by teaching assistants. Classroom presentations, working with individuals, grading, motivating students. Participants will give and critique presentations and may be videotaped while teaching.

IN4MATX 43.title: Introduction to Software Engineering
IN4MATX 43.description: Concepts, methods, and current practice of software engineering. Large-scale software production, software life cycle models, principles and techniques for each stage of development.
IN4MATX 43.restriction: : School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 80.title: Special Topics in Informatics
IN4MATX 80.description: Designed for informatics instructors to pilot new teaching materials and prototype new class. The format of the class is flexible based on the content to be offered in the future.
IN4MATX 80.restriction: : School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX H81.title: Ethics, Technology, and Design
IN4MATX H81.description: Provides a critical framework for how and why biases of many kinds are built into everyday digital tools. Reflections on ethics, technology, and design through case studies drawn from machine learning, CS education, engineering, social media, and criminal justice.

IN4MATX 101.title: Concepts in Programming Languages I
IN4MATX 101.description: In-depth study of several contemporary programming languages stressing variety in data structures, operations, notation, and control. Examination of different programming paradigms, such as logic programming, functional programming and object-oriented programming; implementation strategies, programming environments, and programming style.
IN4MATX 101.prerequisites: (I&C SCI 51 or CSE 31 or EECS 31) and (I&C SCI 46 or CSE 46). I&C SCI 51 with a grade of C or better. CSE 31 with a grade of C or better. EECS 31 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 46 with a grade of C or better. CSE 46 with a grade of C or better
IN4MATX 101.restriction: : School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 102.title: Concepts of Programming Language II
IN4MATX 102.description: In-depth study of major programming paradigms: imperative, functional, declarative, object-oriented, and aspect-oriented. Understanding the role of programming languages in software development and the suitability of languages in context. Domain-specific languages. Designing new languages for better software development support.
IN4MATX 102.restriction: : School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 113.title: Requirements Analysis and Engineering
IN4MATX 113.description: Equips students to develop techniques of software-intensive systems through successful requirements analysis techniques and requirements engineering. Students learn systematic process of developing requirements through cooperative problem analysis, representation, and validation.
IN4MATX 113.prerequisites: (I&C SCI 33 or CSE 43) and IN4MATX 43. I&C SCI 33 with a grade of C or better. CSE 43 with a grade of C or better. IN4MATX 43 with a grade of C or better
IN4MATX 113.restriction: : School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 115.title: Software Testing, Analysis, and Quality Assurance
IN4MATX 115.description: Preparation for developing high-quality software through successful veriﬁcation and validation techniques. Fundamental principles of software testing, implementing software testing practices, ensuring the thoroughness of testing to gain conﬁdence in the correctness of the software.
IN4MATX 115.prerequisites: (I&C SCI 45J or I&C SCI 45C or I&C SCI 46 or CSE 46) and IN4MATX 43. I&C SCI 45J with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 45C with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 46 with a grade of C or better. CSE 46 with a grade of C or better. IN4MATX 43 with a grade of C or better
IN4MATX 115.restriction: : School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 117.title: Project in Software System Design
IN4MATX 117.description: Specification, design, construction, testing, and documentation of a complete software system. Special emphasis on the need for and use of teamwork, careful planning, and other techniques for working with large systems.
IN4MATX 117.restriction: : Upper-division students only. School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 121.title: Software Design: Applications
IN4MATX 121.description: Introduction to application design: designing the overall functionality of a software application. Topics include general design theory, software design theory, and software architecture. Includes practice in designing and case studies of existing designs.
IN4MATX 121.prerequisites: I&C SCI 33 or CSE 43 or GDIM 33. I&C SCI 33 with a grade of C or better. CSE 43 with a grade of C or better. GDIM 33 with a grade of C or better
IN4MATX 121.restriction: : Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 122.title: Software Design: Structure and Implementation
IN4MATX 122.description: Introduction to implementation design: designing the internals of a software application. Topics include design aesthetics, design implementation, design recovery, design patterns, and component reuse. Includes practice in designing and case studies of existing designs.
IN4MATX 122.prerequisites: (I&C SCI 45J or I&C SCI 46 or IN4MATX 45) and (IN4MATX 101 or COMPSCI 141 or CSE 141)
IN4MATX 122.restriction: : School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 124.title: Internet Applications Engineering
IN4MATX 124.description: Concepts in Internet applications engineering with emphasis on the Web. Peer-to-Peer and Interoperability. Topics include HTTP and REST, Remote Procedure/Method Calls, Web Services, data representations, content distribution networks, identity management, relevant W3C/IETF standards, and relevant new large-scale computing styles.
IN4MATX 124.restriction: : Upper-division students only. School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 125.title: Computer Game Development
IN4MATX 125.description: Introduction to the principles of interactive 2D and 3D computer game development. Concepts in computer graphics, algorithms, software engineering, art and graphics, music and sound, story analysis, and artificial intelligence are presented and are the basis for student work.
IN4MATX 125.prerequisites: COMPSCI 112 or COMPSCI 171 or IN4MATX 121 or ART 106B or I&C SCI 163 or I&C SCI 166
IN4MATX 125.restriction: : School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 131.title: Human Computer Interaction
IN4MATX 131.description: Basic principles of human-computer interaction (HCI). Introduces students to user interface design techniques, design guidelines, and usability testing. Students gain the ability to design and evaluate user interfaces and become familiar with some of the outstanding research problems in HCI.
IN4MATX 131.prerequisites: I&C SCI 10 or I&C SCI 31 or I&C SCI 32A or CSE 41 or ENGR 10 or ENGRMAE 10 or EECS 10. I&C SCI 10 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 31 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 32A with a grade of C or better. CSE 41 with a grade of C or better. ENGR 10 with a grade of C or better. ENGRMAE 10 with a grade of C or better. EECS 10 with a grade of C or better
IN4MATX 131.restriction: : School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 132.title: Project in Human-Computer Interaction Requirements and Evaluation
IN4MATX 132.description: Students undertake significant projects in the elicitation and specification of HCI requirements and the thorough evaluation of user interfaces.
IN4MATX 132.restriction: : School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 133.title: User Interaction Software
IN4MATX 133.description: Introduction to human-computer interaction programming. Emphasis on current tools, standards, methodologies for implementing effective interaction designs. Widget toolkits, Web interface programming, geo-spatial and map interfaces, mobile phone interfaces.
IN4MATX 133.prerequisites: I&C SCI 45J or I&C SCI 45C. I&C SCI 45J with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 45C with a grade of C or better
IN4MATX 133.restriction: : School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 134.title: Project in User Interaction Software
IN4MATX 134.description: Students complete an end-to-end user interface programming project based on an iterative design paradigm. Topics may include requirements brainstorming, paper prototyping, iterative development, cognitive walk-through, quantitative evaluation, and acceptance testing. Materials fee.
IN4MATX 134.restriction: : School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 141.title: Information Retrieval
IN4MATX 141.description: An introduction to information retrieval including indexing, retrieval, classifying, and clustering text and multimedia documents.
IN4MATX 141.prerequisites: (I&C SCI 45C or I&C SCI 45J) and (STATS 7 or STATS 67). I&C SCI 45C with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 45J with a grade of C or better
IN4MATX 141.restriction: : School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 143.title: Information Visualization
IN4MATX 143.description: Introduction to interactive visual interfaces for large datasets, and to principles of human visual perception and human computer interaction that inform their design. Various applications for data analysis and monitoring are discussed.
IN4MATX 143.prerequisites: (IN4MATX 131 or IN4MATX 43) and (I&C SCI 31 or I&C SCI 32A or CSE 41). IN4MATX 131 with a grade of C or better. IN4MATX 43 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 31 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 32A with a grade of C or better. CSE 41 with a grade of C or better
IN4MATX 143.restriction: : School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 148.title: Project in Ubiquitous Computing
IN4MATX 148.description: Introduction to ubiquitous computing research methods, tools, and techniques. Prototyping, design, and evaluation of physical computing applications, smart environments, embedded systems, and future computing scenarios. Includes hands-on in-class laboratory exercises. Materials fee.
IN4MATX 148.prerequisites: I&C SCI 10 or I&C SCI 31 or CSE 41 or I&C SCI 32A. I&C SCI 10 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 31 with a grade of C or better. CSE 41 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 32A with a grade of C or better
IN4MATX 148.restriction: : Upper-division students only. School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 151.title: Project Management
IN4MATX 151.description: Introduces theoretical and practical aspects of project management. Topics include organizational theory, group behavior, project management skills, case studies, personal and group productivity tools, management of distributed work, stakeholders, consultants, and knowledge management. Students do a project exercise.
IN4MATX 151.restriction: : School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 153.title: Computer Supported Cooperative Work
IN4MATX 153.description: Introduces concepts and principles of collaborative systems. Topics may include shared workspaces, group interaction, workflow, architectures, interaction between social and technical features of group work, and examples of collaborative systems used in real-world settings. Students develop a simple collaborative application.
IN4MATX 153.prerequisites: (IN4MATX 161 or IN4MATX 43) and (I&C SCI 31 or I&C SCI 32A or CSE 41). I&C SCI 31 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 32A with a grade of C or better. CSE 41 with a grade of C or better
IN4MATX 153.restriction: : School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 161.title: Social Analysis of Computing
IN4MATX 161.description: Introduction of computing as a social process. Examines the social opportunities and problems raised by new information technologies, and the consequences of different ways of organizing. Topics include computing and work life, privacy, virtual communities, productivity paradox, systems risks.
IN4MATX 161.prerequisites: I&C SCI 10 or I&C SCI 31 or I&C SCI 32A or CSE 41 or ENGR 10 or EECS 10 or ENGRMAE 10. I&C SCI 10 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 31 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 32A with a grade of C or better. CSE 41 with a grade of C or better. ENGR 10 with a grade of C or better. EECS 10 with a grade of C or better. ENGRMAE 10 with a grade of C or better. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
IN4MATX 161.restriction: : School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 162W.title: Organizational Information Systems
IN4MATX 162W.description: Introduction to role of information systems in organizations, components and structure of organizational information systems, and techniques used in information systems analysis, design, and implementation.
IN4MATX 162W.prerequisites: IN4MATX 161. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

IN4MATX 163.title: Project in the Social and Organizational Impacts of Computing
IN4MATX 163.description: Students undertake projects intended to gather and analyze data from situations in which computers are used, organize and conduct experiments intended to test hypotheses about impacts, and explore the application of concepts learned in previous courses.

IN4MATX 164.title: Children's Learning and Media
IN4MATX 164.description: Examines how popular media may impact how young people learn, develop, and communicate by looking at research related to the impacts of a wide range of popular media including television, video games, digital environments, mobile devices, and other multimedia.
IN4MATX 164.restriction: : Education Sciences Majors only. Informatics Majors only. Informatics Minors only.

IN4MATX 171.title: Introduction to Health Informatics
IN4MATX 171.description: Broad overview of medical informatics for students with varied backgrounds. Electronic medical records, online resources, mobile technologies, patient safety, and computational design. Legal, ethical, and public policy issues. Health systems management. Evaluation and fieldwork for health systems.
IN4MATX 171.prerequisites: WRITING 60 or WRITING 30 or WRITING 31 or HUMAN 1C or HUMAN H1C. WRITING 60 with a grade of C or better. WRITING 30 with a grade of C or better. WRITING 31 with a grade of C or better. HUMAN 1C with a grade of C or better. HUMAN H1C with a grade of C or better
IN4MATX 171.restriction: : Upper-division students only. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

IN4MATX 172.title: Project in Health Informatics
IN4MATX 172.description: Students undertake significant quarter-long projects related to health informatics. Topics may include field evaluations of health care technologies, prototypes, iterative design, and system implementations.

IN4MATX 173.title: Consumer Health Informatics
IN4MATX 173.description: Consumer health informatics is a subfield of health informatics aimed to empower healthcare consumers through a variety of consumer-facing technologies. Covers health behavior change, health literacy, social support, and the design, evaluation, and implementation of major technological applications.
IN4MATX 173.prerequisites: IN4MATX 171 or PUBHLTH 105. IN4MATX 171 with a grade of C or better. PUBHLTH 105 with a grade of C or better
IN4MATX 173.restriction: : Health Informatics Minors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Majors have first consideration for enrollment. School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 174.title: Health Data Analytics
IN4MATX 174.description: The increasing availability of electronic heath data provides an unprecedented opportunity to use data-driven approaches to improve human health. Equips students with essential skills in curating, managing, and analyzing health data, focusing on electronic health records.
IN4MATX 174.prerequisites: IN4MATX 171 or PUBHLTH 105. IN4MATX 171 with a grade of C or better. PUBHLTH 105 with a grade of C or better
IN4MATX 174.restriction: : Public Health Majors have first consideration for enrollment. School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 190.title: Special Topics in Informatics
IN4MATX 190.description: Studies in selected areas of informatics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

IN4MATX 191A.title: Senior Design Project
IN4MATX 191A.description: Group supervised project in which students analyze, specify, design, construct, evaluate, and adapt a significant information processing system. Topics include team management, professional ethics, and systems analysis.
IN4MATX 191A.prerequisites: IN4MATX 113 and IN4MATX 121 and IN4MATX 131 and IN4MATX 151
IN4MATX 191A.restriction: : Seniors only. Software Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Informatics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 191B.title: Senior Design Project
IN4MATX 191B.description: Group supervised project in which students analyze, specify, design, construct, evaluate, and adapt a significant information processing system. Topics include team management, professional ethics, and systems analysis.
IN4MATX 191B.prerequisites: IN4MATX 191A. In Progress (IP) grade for IN4MATX 191A is also accepted.

IN4MATX H198.title: Honors Research
IN4MATX H198.description: Directed independent research in Informatics for honors students.
IN4MATX H198.prerequisites: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
IN4MATX H198.restriction: : Bren School of ICS Honors students only. Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

IN4MATX 199.title: Individual Study
IN4MATX 199.description: Individual research or investigation under the direction of an individual faculty member.

IN4MATX 201.title: Research Methodology for Informatics
IN4MATX 201.description: Introduction to strategies and idioms of research in Informatics. Includes examination of issues in scientific inquiry, qualitative and quantitative methods, and research design. Both classic texts and contemporary research literature are read and analyzed.

IN4MATX 203.title: Qualitative Research Methods in Information Systems
IN4MATX 203.description: Introduction to qualitative research methods used to study computerization and information systems, such as open-ended interviewing, participant observation, and ethnography. Studies of the methods in practice through examination of research literature.
IN4MATX 203.prerequisites: IN4MATX 261 or IN4MATX 251. IN4MATX 261 with a grade of B- or better. IN4MATX 251 with a grade of B- or better

IN4MATX 205.title: Quantitative Research Methods in Information Systems
IN4MATX 205.description: Quantitative research methods used to study computerization and information systems. Design of instruments, sampling, sample sizes, and data analysis. Validity and reliability. Longitudinal versus cross-sectional designs. Analysis of secondary data. Studies of the methods through examination of research literature.
IN4MATX 205.prerequisites: IN4MATX 251 or IN4MATX 261. IN4MATX 251 with a grade of B- or better. IN4MATX 261 with a grade of B- or better. Basic knowledge of elementary statistics is also required.

IN4MATX 207S.title: Doctoral Seminar on Research and Writing
IN4MATX 207S.description: Doctoral seminar centered on original research and writing. Provides a chance for doctoral students at all levels to present original work, brainstorm ongoing issues, and learn to provide and receive critical feedback from peers.

IN4MATX 209S.title: Seminar in Informatics
IN4MATX 209S.description: Current research and research trends in informatics. Forum for presentation and criticism by students of research work in progress.

IN4MATX 231.title: User Interface Design and Evaluation
IN4MATX 231.description: Introduction to the design and evaluation of user interfaces, with an emphasis on methodology. Cognitive principles, design life cycle, on-line and off-line prototyping techniques. Toolkits and architectures for interactive systems. Evaluation techniques, including heuristic and laboratory methods.

IN4MATX 232.title: Research in Human-Centered Computing
IN4MATX 232.description: Introduction to contemporary topics in human-computer interaction, including methods, technologies, design, and evaluation. Emerging application domains and their challenges to traditional research methods. Advanced architectures and technologies. Critical issues.

IN4MATX 241.title: Introduction to Ubiquitous Computing
IN4MATX 241.description: The "disappearing computer" paradigm. Differences to the desktop computing model: applications, interaction in augmented environments, security, alternate media, small operating systems, sensors, and embedded systems design. Evaluation by project work and class participation.

IN4MATX 242.title: Ubiquitous Computing and Interaction
IN4MATX 242.description: Principles and design techniques for ubiquitous computing applications. Conceptual basis for tangible and embodied interaction. Interaction in virtual and augmented environments. Design methods and techniques. Design case studies. Examination by project work.
IN4MATX 242.prerequisites: IN4MATX 231 and IN4MATX 241. IN4MATX 231 with a grade of B- or better. IN4MATX 241 with a grade of B- or better

IN4MATX 244.title: Introduction to Embedded and Ubiquitous Systems
IN4MATX 244.description: Embedded and ubiquitous system technologies including processors, DSP, memory, and software. System interfacing basics; communication strategies; sensors and actuators, mobile and wireless technology. Using pre-designed hardware and software components. Design case studies in wireless, multimedia, and/or networking domains.
IN4MATX 244.prerequisites: I&C SCI 51 and COMPSCI 152 and COMPSCI 161 and (I&C SCI 6N or MATH 3A or MATH 6G or I&C SCI 6D). B.S. degree in Computer Science is also accepted.

IN4MATX 251.title: Computer-Supported Cooperative Work
IN4MATX 251.description: The role of information systems in supporting work in groups and organizations. Examines various technologies designed to support communication, information sharing, and coordination. Focuses on behavioral and social aspects of designing and using group support technologies.

IN4MATX 261.title: Social Analysis of Computing
IN4MATX 261.description: The social and economic impacts of computing and information technologies on groups, organizations, and society. Topics include computerization and changes in the character of work, social control and privacy, electronic communities, and risks of safety-critical systems to people.

IN4MATX 263.title: Computerization, Work, and Organizations
IN4MATX 263.description: Selected topics in the influence of computerization and information systems in transforming work and organizations. Theories of organization and organizational change. Processes by which diverse information technologies influence changes in work and organizations over short and long time periods.
IN4MATX 263.prerequisites: IN4MATX 251 or IN4MATX 261. IN4MATX 251 with a grade of B- or better. IN4MATX 261 with a grade of B- or better

IN4MATX 265.title: Theories of Information Society
IN4MATX 265.description: Social and economic conceptions of information technology. Macrosocial and economic conditions that foster changes in information technologies. Social construction of information and computer technology in professional worlds. Theories of information technology and large-scale social change.
IN4MATX 265.prerequisites: IN4MATX 251 or IN4MATX 261. IN4MATX 251 with a grade of B- or better. IN4MATX 261 with a grade of B- or better

IN4MATX 267.title: Digital Media and Society
IN4MATX 267.description: Selected topics in the technological and social aspects of online interactions, and policy including online games, social media, electronic activism, e-commerce, and digital libraries. Media-theoretic approaches to digital technology. Architectures, infrastructure considerations, and their consequences.

IN4MATX 273.title: Information Technology in Global Sustainability
IN4MATX 273.description: Explores the relationship between recent developments in information technology and the global transition to sustainability. Topics include the role of IT systems in the provision of human needs and wants (e.g., smart grids, food systems, and other IT-enabled infrastructure).

IN4MATX 280.title: Overview of Human-Computer Interaction and Design
IN4MATX 280.description: Introduction to human-computer interaction and user-centered design. The material is focused on laying the groundwork for understanding the history, importance, and methods of human-computer interaction and design.
IN4MATX 280.restriction: : Master of Hum Com Interact Des Degree students only. Graduate students only.

IN4MATX 281.title: User Needs Analysis
IN4MATX 281.description: Understanding the user's context, needs, and preferences. Topics include interviews and observations, modeling the context, flow, culture, space, and artifacts involved in an endeavor, ways of aggregating what is found, and presenting these findings to others.
IN4MATX 281.prerequisites: IN4MATX 280. IN4MATX 280 with a grade of B- or better
IN4MATX 281.restriction: : Graduate students only. Master of Hum Com Interact Des Degree students only.

IN4MATX 282.title: Design and Prototyping
IN4MATX 282.description: Introduction to user-centered design and prototyping. Focused on practical methods for interaction design. Topics include the nature of design and the challenges to creating and evaluating good designs, as well specific skills for designing interactive systems.
IN4MATX 282.prerequisites: IN4MATX 280. IN4MATX 280 with a grade of B- or better

IN4MATX 283.title: User Experience Evaluation
IN4MATX 283.description: Evaluating prototypes and completed systems. Topics include comparative analysis, laboratory experiments, heuristic evaluation, cognitive walkthroughs, surveys, clickstreams, and help-desk.
IN4MATX 283.prerequisites: IN4MATX 280. IN4MATX 280 with a grade of B- or better
IN4MATX 283.restriction: : Graduate students only. Master of Hum Com Interact Des Degree students only.

IN4MATX 284.title: Advanced Design and Prototyping
IN4MATX 284.description: Develop and communicate interactive technology design prototypes. Moving concepts from brainstorming and paper prototypes to wireframe and limited functionality mock-ups.
IN4MATX 284.prerequisites: IN4MATX 282. IN4MATX 282 with a grade of B- or better
IN4MATX 284.restriction: : Graduate students only. Master of Hum Com Interact Des Degree students only.

IN4MATX 285.title: Interactive Technology Studio
IN4MATX 285.description: Technologies, languages, and skills required for creating prototypes to communicate interactive technology concepts. Topics include HTTP, CSS, CSS scripting, AJAX, Design Patterns, Javascript, Javascript libraries such as jQuery, SQL, MVC, and cloud architectures.
IN4MATX 285.prerequisites: IN4MATX 280. IN4MATX 280 with a grade of B- or better
IN4MATX 285.restriction: : Graduate students only. Master of Hum Com Interact Des Degree students only.

IN4MATX 286.title: Innovations in HCI and Design
IN4MATX 286.description: Recent social and technological developments in human-computer interaction and design. Topics will vary as the field progresses but include novel input techniques, novel platforms, and innovations in theory and methods of design.
IN4MATX 286.prerequisites: IN4MATX 280. IN4MATX 280 with a grade of B- or better

IN4MATX 287.title: Capstone Project in HCI and Design
IN4MATX 287.description: Group project that reinforces all concepts learned in this program, including knowing where user experience work is most appropriate and essential, and executing the appropriate steps.
IN4MATX 287.prerequisites: IN4MATX 283 and IN4MATX 284. IN4MATX 283 with a grade of B- or better. IN4MATX 284 with a grade of B- or better
IN4MATX 287.restriction: : Graduate students only. Human Comp Interact and Design Majors only.

IN4MATX 288.title: Capstone Project and Portfolio
IN4MATX 288.description: Completion of capstone projects and development of portfolios. Ideation, critique, development, and critique.
IN4MATX 288.prerequisites: IN4MATX 287. IN4MATX 287 with a grade of B- or better

IN4MATX 289.title: Special Topics in Applying Human-Computer Interaction and Design in Industry
IN4MATX 289.description: Selected topics related to understanding and applying human-computer interaction and design concepts and practices within the User Experience industry. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
IN4MATX 289.restriction: : School of Info & Computer Sci students only. Graduate students only. Human Comp Interact and Design Majors only.

IN4MATX 290.title: Research Seminar
IN4MATX 290.description: Forum for presentation and criticism by students of research work in progress. Presentation of problem areas and related work. Specific goals and progress of research.

IN4MATX 295.title: Special Topics in Informatics
IN4MATX 295.description: Studies in selected areas of informatics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

IN4MATX 298.title: Thesis Supervision
IN4MATX 298.description: Individual research or investigation conducted in preparation for the M.S. thesis option or the dissertation requirements for the Ph.D. program.

IN4MATX 299.title: Individual Study
IN4MATX 299.description: Individual research or investigation under the direction of an individual faculty member.

STATS 5.title: Seminar in Data Science
STATS 5.description: An introduction to the field of Data Science; intended for entering freshman and transfers.

STATS 6.title: Introduction to Data Science
STATS 6.description: Introduces the full data cycle. Topics include data collection and retrieval, data cleaning, exploratory analysis and visualization, introduction to statistical modeling, inference, and communicating findings. Applications include real data from a wide-range of fields with emphasis on understanding reproducible practices.

STATS 7.title: Basic Statistics
STATS 7.description: Introduces basic inferential statistics including confidence intervals and hypothesis testing on means and proportions, t-distribution, Chi Square, regression and correlation. F-distribution and nonparametric statistics included if time permits.
STATS 7.restriction: : STATS 7 may not be taken for credit concurrently with or after STATS 110, STATS 111, STATS 112.

STATS 8.title: Introduction to Biological Statistics
STATS 8.description: Introductory statistical techniques used to collect and analyze experimental and observational data from health sciences and biology. Includes exploration of data, probability and sampling distributions, basic statistical inference for means and proportions, linear regression, and analysis of variance.
STATS 8.restriction: : STATS 8 may not be taken for credit concurrently with or after STATS 110, STATS 111, STATS 112.

STATS 67.title: Introduction to Probability and Statistics for Computer Science
STATS 67.description: Introduction to the basic concepts of probability and statistics with discussion of applications to computer science.
STATS 67.restriction: : School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. STATS 67 may not be taken for credit concurrently with or after STATS 120B.

STATS 68.title: Statistical Computing and Exploratory Data Analysis
STATS 68.description: Introduces key concepts in statistical computing. Techniques such as exploratory data analysis, data visualization, simulation, and optimization methods, are presented in the context of data analysis within a statistical computing environment.
STATS 68.prerequisites: STATS 7 and (I&C SCI 31 or I&C SCI 32A)

STATS 110.title: Statistical Methods for Data Analysis I
STATS 110.description: Introduction to statistical methods for analyzing data from experiments and surveys. Methods covered include two-sample procedures, analysis of variance, simple and multiple linear regression.
STATS 110.prerequisites: STATS 7 or STATS 8 or AP Statistics or (STATS 120A and STATS 120B and STATS 120C). AP Statistics with a minimum score of 3
STATS 110.restriction: : School of Info & Computer Sci students only.

STATS 111.title: Statistical Methods for Data Analysis II
STATS 111.description: Introduction to statistical methods for analyzing data from surveys or experiments. Emphasizes application and understanding of methods for categorical data including contingency tables, logistic and Poisson regression, loglinear models.

STATS 112.title: Statistical Methods for Data Analysis III
STATS 112.description: Introduction to statistical methods for analyzing longitudinal data from experiments and cohort studies. Topics covered include survival methods for censored time-to-event data, linear mixed models, non-linear mixed effects models, and generalized estimating equations.

STATS 115.title: Introduction to Bayesian Data Analysis
STATS 115.description: Basic Bayesian concepts and methods with emphasis on data analysis. Prior and posterior probability distributions, modeling, and Markov Chain Monte Carlo techniques are presented in the context of data analysis within a statistical computing environment.

STATS 120A.title: Introduction to Probability and Statistics I
STATS 120A.description: Introduction to basic principles of probability and statistical inference. Axiomatic definition of probability, random variables, probability distributions, expectation.
STATS 120A.prerequisites: MATH 2A and MATH 2B and (MATH 2D or MATH 4)
STATS 120A.restriction: : Data Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics majors have second consideration.

STATS 120B.title: Introduction to Probability and Statistics II
STATS 120B.description: Introduction to basic principles of probability and statistical inference. Point estimation, interval estimating, and testing hypotheses, Bayesian approaches to inference.
STATS 120B.restriction: : Data Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics majors have second consideration.

STATS 120C.title: Introduction to Probability and Statistics III
STATS 120C.description: Introduction to basic principles of probability and statistical inference. Linear regression, analysis or variance, model checking.
STATS 120C.prerequisites: STATS 120B and (MATH 3A or MATH 6G or I&C SCI 6N)
STATS 120C.restriction: : Data Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics majors have second consideration.

STATS 140.title: Multivariate Statistical Methods
STATS 140.description: Theory and application of multivariate statistical methods. Topics include statistical inference for the multivariate normal model and its extensions to multiple samples and regression, use of statistical packages for data visualization and reduction, discriminant analysis, cluster analysis, and factor analysis.

STATS 170A.title: Project in Data Science I
STATS 170A.description: Problem definition and analysis, data representation, algorithm selection, solution validation, and results presentation. Students do team projects and lectures cover analysis alternatives, project planning, and data analysis issues. First quarter emphasizes approach selection, project planning, and experimental design.
STATS 170A.restriction: : Seniors only. Data Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

STATS 170B.title: Project in Data Science II
STATS 170B.description: Problem definition and analysis, data representation, algorithm selection, solution validation, and results presentation. Students do team projects and lectures cover analysis alternatives, project planning, and data analysis issues. Second quarter emphasizes project execution and analysis, and presentation of results.
STATS 170B.restriction: : Seniors only. Data Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

STATS 199.title: Individual Study
STATS 199.description: Individual research or investigations under the direction of an individual faculty member.

STATS 200A.title: Intermediate Probability and Statistical Theory
STATS 200A.description: Basics of probability theory, random variables and basic transformations, univariate distributions—discrete and continuous, multivariate distributions.
STATS 200A.prerequisites: STATS 120C. STATS 120C with a grade of B- or better

STATS 200B.title: Intermediate Probability and Statistical Theory
STATS 200B.description: Random samples, transformations, limit laws, normal distribution theory, introduction to stochastic processes, data reduction, point estimation (maximum likelihood).
STATS 200B.prerequisites: STATS 200A. STATS 200A with a grade of B- or better

STATS 200C.title: Intermediate Probability and Statistical Theory
STATS 200C.description: Interval estimation, hypothesis testing, decision theory and Bayesian inference, basic linear model theory.
STATS 200C.prerequisites: STATS 200B. STATS 200B with a grade of B- or better

STATS 201.title: Statistical Methods for Data Analysis I
STATS 201.description: Introduction to statistical methods for analyzing data from experiments and surveys. Methods covered include two-sample procedures, analysis of variance, simple and multiple linear regression.
STATS 201.restriction: : STATS 201 cannot be taken for credit after taking STATS 210.

STATS 202.title: Statistical Methods for Data Analysis II
STATS 202.description: Introduction to statistical methods for analyzing data from surveys or experiments. Emphasizes application and understanding of methods for categorical data including contingency tables, logistic and Poisson regression, loglinear models.
STATS 202.prerequisites: STATS 201 or STATS 210. STATS 201 with a grade of B- or better. STATS 210 with a grade of B- or better

STATS 203.title: Statistical Methods for Data Analysis III
STATS 203.description: Introduction to statistical methods for analyzing longitudinal data from experiments and cohort studies. Topics covered include survival methods for censored time-to-event data, linear mixed models, non-linear mixed effects models, and generalized estimating equations.
STATS 203.prerequisites: STATS 202. STATS 202 with a grade of B- or better

STATS 205.title: Introduction to Bayesian Data Analysis
STATS 205.description: Basic Bayesian concepts and methods with emphasis on data analysis.  Special emphasis on specification of prior distributions.  Development for one-two samples and on to binary, Poisson and linear regression.  Analyses performed using free OpenBugs software.

STATS 205P.title: Bayesian Data Analysis
STATS 205P.description: Covers basic Bayesian concepts and methods with emphasis on data analysis. Special emphasis on specification of prior distributions. Development of methods and theory for one and two samples, binary, Poisson, and linear regression.
STATS 205P.prerequisites: DATA 200AP and DATA 200BP and DATA 210P. DATA 200AP with a grade of B or better. DATA 200BP with a grade of B or better. DATA 210P with a grade of B or better
STATS 205P.restriction: : Graduate students only. Master of Data Science Degree students only.

STATS 210.title: Statistical Methods I: Linear Models
STATS 210.description: Statistical methods for analyzing data from surveys and experiments. Topics include randomization and model-based inference, two-sample methods, analysis of variance, linear regression and model diagnostics.
STATS 210.prerequisites: Knowledge of basic statistics, calculus, linear algebra.

STATS 210A.title: Statistical Methods I: Linear Models
STATS 210A.description: Statistical methods for analyzing data from surveys and experiments. Topics include randomization and model-based inference, two-sample methods, analysis of variance, linear regression, and model diagnostics.
STATS 210A.prerequisites: Knowledge of basic statistics (at the level of STATS 7), calculus, and linear algebra.

STATS 210B.title: Statistical Methods II: Categorical Data
STATS 210B.description: Introduction to statistical methods for analyzing discrete and non-normal outcomes. Emphasizes the development and application of methods for categorical data, including contingency tables, logistic and Poisson regression, loglinear models.
STATS 210B.prerequisites: STATS 210. STATS 210 with a grade of B- or better. May not be taken for graduate credit by Ph.D. students in Statistics.

STATS 210C.title: Statistical Methods III: Longitudinal Data
STATS 210C.description: Introduction to statistical methods for analyzing longitudinal outcomes. Emphasizes the development and application of regression methods for correlated and censored outcomes. Methods for continuous and discrete correlated outcomes, as well as censored outcomes, are covered.
STATS 210C.prerequisites: STATS 210B. STATS 210B with a grade of B- or better. May not be taken for graduate credit by Ph.D. students in Statistics.

STATS 211.title: Statistical Methods II: Generalized Linear Models
STATS 211.description: Development of the theory and application of generalized linear models. Topics include likelihood estimation and asymptotic distributional theory for exponential families, quasi-likelihood and mixed model development. Emphasizes methodological development and application to real scientific problems.
STATS 211.prerequisites: or corequisite: STATS 210. STATS 210 with a grade of B- or better

STATS 212.title: Statistical Methods III: Methods for Correlated Data
STATS 212.description: Development and application of statistical methods for analyzing corrected data. Topics covered include repeated measures ANOVA, linear mixed models, non-linear mixed effects models, and generalized estimating equations.  Emphasizes both theoretical development and application of the presented methodology.
STATS 212.prerequisites: STATS 211. STATS 211 with a grade of B- or better

STATS 220A.title: Advanced Probability and Statistics Topics
STATS 220A.description: Advanced topics in probability and statistical inference including measure theoretic probability, large sample theory, decision theory, resampling and Monte Carlo methods, nonparametric methods.
STATS 220A.prerequisites: STATS 200C. STATS 200C with a grade of B- or better

STATS 220B.title: Advanced Probability and Statistics Topics
STATS 220B.description: Advanced topics in probability and statistical inference, including measure theoretic probability, large sample theory, decision theory, resampling and Monte Carlo methods, nonparametric methods.
STATS 220B.prerequisites: STATS 220A and MATH 140B. STATS 220A with a grade of B- or better

STATS 225.title: Bayesian Statistical Analysis
STATS 225.description: Introduction to the Bayesian approach to statistical inference. Topics include univariate and multivariate models, choice of prior distributions, hierarchical models, computation including Markov chain Monte Carlo, model checking, and model selection.
STATS 225.prerequisites: STATS 205 and STATS 230. STATS 205 with a grade of B- or better. STATS 230 with a grade of B- or better

STATS 230.title: Statistical Computing Methods
STATS 230.description: Numerical computations and algorithms with applications in statistics. Topics include optimization methods including the EM algorithm, random number generation and simulation, Markov chain simulation tools, and numerical integration.
STATS 230.prerequisites: Two quarters of upper-division or graduate training in probability and statistics.

STATS 240.title: Multivariate Statistical Methods
STATS 240.description: Theory and application of multivariate statistical methods. Topics include statistical inference for the multivariate normal model and its extensions to multiple samples and regression, use of statistical packages for data visualization and reduction, discriminant analysis, cluster analysis, and factor analysis.

STATS 240P.title: Multivariate Statistical Methods
STATS 240P.description: Theory and application of multivariate statistical methods. Topics include statistical inference for the multivariate normal model and its extensions to multiple samples and regression, use of statistical packages for data visualization and dimension reduction, discriminant analysis, cluster analysis, factor analysis.
STATS 240P.prerequisites: DATA 200AP and DATA 200BP. DATA 200AP with a grade of B- or better. DATA 200BP with a grade of B- or better
STATS 240P.restriction: : Graduate students only. Master of Data Science Degree students only.

STATS 245.title: Time Series Analysis
STATS 245.description: Statistical models for analysis of time series from time and frequency domain perspectives. Emphasizes theory and application of time series data analysis methods. Topics include ARMA/ARIMA models, model identification/estimation, linear operators, Fourier analysis, spectral estimation, state space models, Kalman filter.

STATS 245P.title: Time Series Analysis
STATS 245P.description: Statistical models for time series. Topics include linear models for trends; stationary time-series; non-stationary time series; forecasting and Kalman filtering; time-series smoothing; seasonal models; ARCH, GARCH and stochastic volatility models; multivariate time series; vector autoregressive models; spectral analysis; case studies.
STATS 245P.prerequisites: DATA 200AP and DATA 200BP. DATA 200AP with a grade of B- or better. DATA 200BP with a grade of B- or better
STATS 245P.restriction: : Graduate students only. Master of Data Science Degree students only.

STATS 255.title: Statistical Methods for Survival Data
STATS 255.description: Statistical methods for analyzing survival data from cohort studies. Topics include parametric and nonparametric methods, the Kaplan-Meier estimator, log-rank tests, regression models, the Cox proportional hazards model and accelerated failure time models, efficient sampling designs, discrete survival models.

STATS 260.title: Inference with Missing Data
STATS 260.description: Statistical methods and theory useful for analysis of multivariate data with partially observed variables. Bayesian and likelihood-based methods developed. Topics include EM-type algorithms, MCMC samplers, multiple imputation, and general location model. Applications from economics, education, and medicine are discussed.

STATS 262P.title: Theory and Practice of Sample Survey
STATS 262P.description: Basic techniques and statistical methods for designing surveys and analyzing collected survey data. Topics include simple random sampling, ratio and regression estimates, stratified sampling, cluster sampling, sampling with unequal probabilities, multistage sampling, and methods to handle nonresponse.
STATS 262P.prerequisites: DATA 200AP and DATA 200BP. DATA 200AP with a grade of B or better. DATA 200BP with a grade of B or better
STATS 262P.restriction: : Graduate students only. Master of Data Science Degree students only.

STATS 265.title: Causal Inference
STATS 265.description: Various approaches to causal inference focusing on the Rubin causal model and propensity-score methods. Topics include randomized experiments, observational studies, non-compliance, ignorable and non-ignorable treatment assignment, instrumental variables, and sensitivity analysis. Applications from economics, politics, education, and medicine.
STATS 265.prerequisites: STATS 200C and STATS 210. STATS 200C with a grade of B- or better. STATS 210 with a grade of B- or better

STATS 270.title: Stochastic Processes
STATS 270.description: Introduction to the theory and application of stochastic processes. Topics include Markov chains, continuous-time Markov processes, Poisson processes, and Brownian motion. Applications include Markov chain Monte Carlo methods and financial modeling (for example, option pricing).

STATS 270P.title: Stochastic Processes
STATS 270P.description: Introduction to the theory and application of stochastic processes. Topics include Poisson processes, Markov chains, continuous-time Markov processes, and Brownian motion. Applications include Markov chain Monte Carlo methods and financial modeling (e.g. option pricing).
STATS 270P.prerequisites: DATA 200AP and DATA 200BP. DATA 200AP with a grade of B or better. DATA 200BP with a grade of B or better
STATS 270P.restriction: : Graduate students only. Master of Data Science Degree students only.

STATS 275.title: Statistical Consulting
STATS 275.description: Training in collaborative research and practical application of statistics. Emphasis on effective communication as it relates to identifying scientific objectives, formulating a statistical analysis plan, choice of statistical methods, and interpretation of results and their limitations to non-statisticians.
STATS 275.prerequisites: STATS 203 or STATS 212 or STATS 210C. STATS 203 with a grade of B or better. STATS 212 with a grade of B or better. STATS 210C with a grade of B or better

STATS 280.title: Seminar in Statistics
STATS 280.description: Periodic seminar series covering topics of current research in statistics and its application.

STATS 281A.title: Introduction to Probability and Statistics I
STATS 281A.description: Introduction to basic principles of probability and statistical inference. Axiomatic definition of probability, random variables, probability distributions, expectation.

STATS 281B.title: Introduction to Probability and Statistics II
STATS 281B.description: Introduction to basic principles of probability and statistical inference. Point estimation, interval estimating, and testing hypotheses, Bayesian approaches to inference.

STATS 281C.title: Introduction to Probability and Statistics III
STATS 281C.description: Introduction to basic principles of probability and statistical inference. Contingency table analysis, linear regression, analysis of variance, model checking.

STATS 295.title: Special Topics in Statistics
STATS 295.description: Studies in selected areas of statistics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

STATS 298.title: Thesis Supervision
STATS 298.description: Individual research or investigation conducted in preparation for the M.S. thesis option or the dissertation requirements for the Ph.D. program.

STATS 299.title: Individual Study
STATS 299.description: Individual research or investigation under the direction of an individual faculty member.

MATH 1A.title: Pre-Calculus I
MATH 1A.description: Basic equations and inequalities, linear and quadratic functions, and systems of simultaneous equations.
MATH 1A.grading_option: Workload Credit Letter Grade with P/NP.

MATH 1B.title: Pre-Calculus II
MATH 1B.description: Preparation for calculus and other mathematics courses. Exponentials, logarithms, trigonometry, polynomials, and rational functions. Satisfies no requirements other than contribution to the 180 units required for graduation.
MATH 1B.prerequisites: Recommended: A passing score on the Pre-Calculus Self-Assessment exam, or a score of 450 or higher on the Mathematics section of the SAT Reasoning Test. Not for students with a score of 3 or higher on the AP Calc AB exam. Not for students with a score of 3 or higher on the AP Calc BC exam.
MATH 1B.restriction: : MATH 1B may not be taken for credit if taken after MATH 2A.

MATH 2A.title: Single-Variable Calculus I
MATH 2A.description: Introduction to derivatives, calculation of derivatives of algebraic and trigonometric functions; applications including curve sketching, related rates, and optimization. Exponential and logarithm functions.
MATH 2A.prerequisites: MATH 1B or SAT Mathematics or ACT Mathematics. MATH 1B with a grade of C- or better. SAT Mathematics with a minimum score of 650. ACT Mathematics with a minimum score of 29. Placement via the Calculus Placement exam (fee required) is also accepted.
MATH 2A.restriction: : School of Physical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 2B.title: Single-Variable Calculus II
MATH 2B.description: Definite integrals; the fundamental theorem of calculus. Applications of integration including finding areas and volumes. Techniques of integration. Infinite sequences and series.
MATH 2B.prerequisites: MATH 2A or MATH 5A or MATH 7A or AP Calculus AB or AP Calculus BC. AP Calculus AB with a minimum score of 3. AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 3
MATH 2B.restriction: : School of Physical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 2D.title: Multivariable Calculus I
MATH 2D.description: Differential and integral calculus of real-valued functions of several real variables, including applications. Polar coordinates.
MATH 2D.prerequisites: MATH 2B or MATH 5B or MATH 7B or AP Calculus BC. AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 4
MATH 2D.restriction: : School of Physical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Undeclared Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 2E.title: Multivariable Calculus II
MATH 2E.description: The differential and integral calculus of vector-valued functions. Implicit and inverse function theorems. Line and surface integrals, divergence and curl, theorems of Greens, Gauss, and Stokes.
MATH 2E.restriction: : School of Physical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH H2D.title: Honors Multivariable Calculus I
MATH H2D.description: Differential and integral calculus of real-valued functions of several real variables, including applications. Polar coordinates. Covers the same material as MATH 2D-E, but with a greater emphasis on the theoretical structure of the subject matter.
MATH H2D.prerequisites: MATH 2B or MATH 5B or MATH 7B or (AP Calculus BC and (MATH H3A or MATH 3A)). MATH 2B with a grade of A or better. MATH 5B with a grade of A or better. MATH 7B with a grade of A or better. AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 5. MATH H3A with a grade of B- or better. MATH 3A with a grade of A or better

MATH H2E.title: Honors Multivariable Calculus II
MATH H2E.description: Differential and integral calculus of real-valued functions of several real variables, including applications. Polar coordinates. Covers the same material as MATH 2D-E, but with a greater emphasis on the theoretical structure of the subject matter.
MATH H2E.prerequisites: MATH H2D. MATH H2D with a grade of B- or better

MATH 3A.title: Introduction to Linear Algebra
MATH 3A.description: Systems of linear equations, matrix operations, determinants, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, vector spaces, subspaces, and dimension.
MATH 3A.prerequisites: MATH 2B or MATH 5B or MATH 7B or AP Calculus BC. AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 4
MATH 3A.restriction: : Undeclared Majors have first consideration for enrollment. School of Physical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 3D.title: Elementary Differential Equations
MATH 3D.description: Linear differential equations, variation of parameters, constant coefficient cookbook, systems of equations, Laplace transforms, series solutions.
MATH 3D.prerequisites: (MATH 3A or MATH H3A) and (MATH 2D or MATH H2D)
MATH 3D.restriction: : School of Physical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH H3A.title: Honors Introduction to Linear Algebra
MATH H3A.description: Systems of linear equations, matrix operations, determinants, eigenvalues, eigenvectors, vector spaces, subspaces, and dimension.
MATH H3A.prerequisites: MATH 2B or MATH 5B or MATH 7B or AP Calculus BC. MATH 2B with a grade of A or better. MATH 5B with a grade of A or better. MATH 7B with a grade of A or better. AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 5
MATH H3A.restriction: : School of Physical Sciences students only. School of Engineering students only. Mathematics Majors only. Undeclared Majors only.

MATH 5A.title: Calculus for Life Sciences I
MATH 5A.description: Differential calculus with applications to life sciences. Exponential, logarithmic, and trigonometric functions. Limits, differentiation techniques, optimization and difference equations.
MATH 5A.prerequisites: MATH 1B or SAT Mathematics or ACT Mathematics. MATH 1B with a grade of C- or better. SAT Mathematics with a minimum score of 650. ACT Mathematics with a minimum score of 29. Placement via the Calculus Placement exam (fee required) is also accepted.
MATH 5A.restriction: : School of Biological Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 5B.title: Calculus for Life Sciences II
MATH 5B.description: Integral calculus and multivariable calculus with applications to life sciences. Integration techniques, applications of the integral, phase plane methods and basic modeling, basic multivariable methods.
MATH 5B.prerequisites: MATH 5A or MATH 2A or MATH 7A or AP Calculus AB or AP Calculus BC. AP Calculus AB with a minimum score of 3. AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 3
MATH 5B.restriction: : School of Biological Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. Cannot be taken for credit after MATH 2B.

MATH 8.title: Explorations in Functions and Modeling
MATH 8.description: Explorations of applications and connections in topics in algebra, geometry, calculus, and statistics for future secondary math educators. Emphasis on nonstandard modeling problems.

MATH 9.title: Introduction to Programming for Numerical Analysis
MATH 9.description: Introduction to computers and programming using Matlab and Python. Representation of numbers and precision, input/output, functions, custom data types, testing/debugging, reading exceptions, plotting data, numerical differentiation, basics of algorithms. Analysis of random processes using computer simulations.
MATH 9.prerequisites: MATH 2A or MATH 5A or MATH 7A or AP Calculus AB or AP Calculus BC. AP Calculus AB with a minimum score of 3. AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 3
MATH 9.restriction: : Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 10.title: Introduction to Programming for Data Science
MATH 10.description: Introduction to Python for data science. Selecting appropriate data types; functions and methods; plotting; the libraries NumPy, pandas, scikit-learn. Foundations of machine learning.
MATH 10.restriction: : Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 13.title: Introduction to Abstract Mathematics
MATH 13.description: Introduction to formal definition and rigorous proof writing in mathematics. Topics include basic logic, set theory, equivalence relations, and various proof techniques such as direct, induction, contradiction, contrapositive, and exhaustion.
MATH 13.prerequisites: MATH 2A or MATH 5A or MATH 7A or I&C SCI 6D or AP Calculus AB or AP Calculus BC. AP Calculus AB with a minimum score of 3. AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 3
MATH 13.restriction: : Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 99.title: New Math Major Seminar for First-Year and Transfer Students
MATH 99.description: A series of presentations and activities to help first-year and transfer students transition to the UCI mathematics majors. Presentations are given by faculty, current students, and school staff to ensure that students make the most of the math major.
MATH 99.restriction: : New math majors only, including transfer students majoring in math.

MATH 105A.title: Numerical Analysis I
MATH 105A.description: Introduction to the theory and practice of numerical computation with an emphasis on solving equations. Solving transcendental equations; linear systems, Gaussian elimination, QR factorization, iterative methods, eigenvalue computation, power method.

MATH 105B.title: Numerical Analysis II
MATH 105B.description: Introduction to the theory and practice of numerical computation with an emphasis on topics from calculus and approximation theory. Lagrange interpolation; Gaussian quadrature; Fourier series and transforms; Methods from data science including least squares and L1 regression.

MATH 105LA.title: Numerical Analysis Laboratory
MATH 105LA.description: Provides practical experience to complement the theory developed in Mathematics 105A.

MATH 105LB.title: Numerical Analysis Laboratory
MATH 105LB.description: Provides practical experience to complement the theory developed in Mathematics 105B.

MATH 107.title: Numerical Differential Equations
MATH 107.description: Theory and applications of numerical methods to initial and boundary-value problems for ordinary and partial differential equations.

MATH 107L.title: Numerical Differential Equations Laboratory
MATH 107L.description: Provides practical experience to complement the theory developed in Mathematics 107.

MATH 110A.title: Optimization I
MATH 110A.description: Introduction to optimization, linear search method, trust region method, Newton method, linear programming, linear, and non-linear least square methods.
MATH 110A.restriction: : Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 110B.title: Optimization II
MATH 110B.description: The simplex method, interior point method, penalty barrier method, primal dual method, augmented Lagrangian method, and stochastic gradient method.
MATH 110B.prerequisites: MATH 110A. MATH 110A with a grade of C- or better
MATH 110B.restriction: : Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 112A.title: Introduction to Partial Differential Equations and Applications I
MATH 112A.description: Introduction to ordinary and partial differential equations and their applications in engineering and science. Basic methods for classical PDEs (potential, heat, and wave equations). Classification of PDEs, separation of variables and series expansions, special functions, eigenvalue problems.

MATH 112B.title: Introduction to Partial Differential Equations and Applications II
MATH 112B.description: Introduction to partial differential equations and their applications in engineering and science. Basic methods for classical PDEs (potential, heat, and wave equations). Green functions and integral representations, method of characteristics.

MATH 112C.title: Introduction to Partial Differential Equations and Applications III
MATH 112C.description: Nonhomogeneous problems and Green's functions, Sturm-Liouville theory, general Fourier expansions, applications of partial differential equations in different areas of science.

MATH 113A.title: Mathematical Modeling in Biology I
MATH 113A.description: Discrete mathematical and statistical models; difference equations, population dynamics, Markov chains, and statistical models in biology.
MATH 113A.prerequisites: MATH 2B or MATH 5B or MATH 7B or AP Calculus BC. AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 4

MATH 113B.title: Mathematical Modeling in Biology II
MATH 113B.description: Linear algebra; differential equations models; dynamical systems; stability; hysteresis; phase plane analysis; applications to cell biology, viral dynamics, and infectious diseases.

MATH 115.title: Mathematical Modeling
MATH 115.description: Mathematical modeling and analysis of phenomena that arise in engineering physical sciences, biology, economics, or social sciences.

MATH 117.title: Dynamical Systems
MATH 117.description: Introduction to the modern theory of dynamical systems including contraction mapping principle, fractals and chaos, conservative systems, Kepler problem, billiard models, expanding maps, Smale's horseshoe, topological entropy.

MATH 118.title: The Theory of Differential Equations
MATH 118.description: Existence and uniqueness of solutions, continuous dependence of solutions on initial conditions and parameters, Lyapunov and asymptotic stability, Floquet theory, nonlinear systems, and bifurcations.

MATH 120A.title: Introduction to Abstract Algebra: Groups
