MATH 120A.description: Axioms for group theory; permutation groups, matrix groups. Isomorphisms, homomorphisms, quotient groups. Advanced topics as time permits. Special emphasis on doing proofs.
MATH 120A.prerequisites: (MATH 3A or MATH H3A) and MATH 13. MATH 13 with a grade of C- or better
MATH 120A.restriction: : Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 120B.title: Introduction to Abstract Algebra: Rings and Fields
MATH 120B.description: Basic properties of rings; ideals, quotient rings; polynomial and matrix rings. Elements of field theory.
MATH 120B.prerequisites: MATH 120A. MATH 120A with a grade of C- or better
MATH 120B.restriction: : Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 120C.title: Introduction to Abstract Algebra: Galois Theory
MATH 120C.description: Galois Theory: proof of the impossibility of certain ruler-and-compass constructions (squaring the circle, trisecting angles); nonexistence of analogues to the "quadratic formula" for polynomial equations of degree 5 or higher.

MATH H120A.title: Honors Introduction to Graduate Algebra I
MATH H120A.description: Introduction to abstract linear algebra, including bases, linear transformation, eigenvectors, canonical forms, inner products, and symmetric operators. Introduction to groups, rings, and fields, including examples of groups, group actions, Sylow theorems, modules over principal ideal domains, polynomials, and Galois groups.
MATH H120A.prerequisites: (MATH 3A or MATH H3A) and MATH 13 and (MATH 120A or MATH 121A). MATH 13 with a grade of A or better. MATH 120A with a grade of A or better. MATH 121A with a grade of A or better

MATH H120B.title: Honors Introduction to Graduate Algebra II
MATH H120B.description: Introduction to abstract linear algebra, including bases, linear transformation, eigenvectors, canonical forms, inner products, and symmetric operators. Introduction to groups, rings, and fields, including examples of groups, group actions, Sylow theorems, modules over principal ideal domains, polynomials, and Galois groups.

MATH H120C.title: Honors Introduction to Graduate Algebra III
MATH H120C.description: Introduction to abstract linear algebra, including bases, linear transformation, eigenvectors, canonical forms, inner products, and symmetric operators. Introduction to groups, rings, and fields, including examples of groups, group actions, Sylow theorems, modules over principal ideal domains, polynomials, and Galois groups.

MATH 121A.title: Linear Algebra I
MATH 121A.description: Introduction to modern abstract linear algebra. Special emphasis on students doing proofs. Vector spaces, linear independence, bases, dimension. Linear transformations and their matrix representations. Theory of determinants.
MATH 121A.prerequisites: (MATH 3A or MATH H3A) and MATH 13. MATH 13 with a grade of C- or better
MATH 121A.restriction: : Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 121B.title: Linear Algebra II
MATH 121B.description: Introduction to modern abstract linear algebra. Special emphasis on students doing proofs. Canonical forms; inner products; similarity of matrices.
MATH 121B.prerequisites: MATH 121A. MATH 121A with a grade of C- or better
MATH 121B.restriction: : Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 130A.title: Probability I
MATH 130A.description: Combinatorial probability, conditional probabilities, independence, discrete and continuous random variables, expectation and variance, common probability distributions.

MATH 130B.title: Probability II
MATH 130B.description: Joint distributions, sums of independent random variables, conditional distributions and conditional expectation, covariances, moment generating functions, limit theorems.

MATH 130C.title: Stochastic Processes
MATH 130C.description: Markov chains, Brownian motion, Gaussian processes, applications to option pricing and Markov chain Monte Carlo methods.

MATH 134A.title: Fixed Income
MATH 134A.description: Overview of interest theory, time value of money, annuities/cash flows with payments that are not contingent, loans, sinking funds, bonds, general cash flow and portfolios, immunization, duration and convexity, swaps.

MATH 134B.title: Mathematics of Financial Derivatives
MATH 134B.description: General derivatives; call/put options; hedging and investment strategies: spreads and collars; risk management; forwards and futures; bonds.
MATH 134B.prerequisites: MATH 130A. MATH 130A with a grade of C- or better

MATH 134C.title: Mathematical Models for Finance
MATH 134C.description: General properties of options: option contracts (call and put options, European, American and exotic options); binomial option pricing model, Black-Scholes option pricing model; risk-neutral pricing formula using Monte-Carlo simulation; option greeks and risk management; interest rate derivatives, Markowitz portfolio theory.
MATH 134C.restriction: : Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 140A.title: Elementary Analysis I
MATH 140A.description: Introduction to real analysis, including convergence of sequence, infinite series, differentiation and integration, and sequences of functions. Students are expected to do proofs.
MATH 140A.prerequisites: (MATH 2D or MATH H2D) and (MATH 3A or MATH H3A) and MATH 13. MATH 13 with a grade of C- or better
MATH 140A.restriction: : Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 140B.title: Elementary Analysis II
MATH 140B.description: Introduction to real analysis including convergence of sequences, infinite series, differentiation and integration, and sequences of functions. Students are expected to do proofs.
MATH 140B.prerequisites: MATH 140A. MATH 140A with a grade of C- or better
MATH 140B.restriction: : Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 140C.title: Analysis in Several Variables
MATH 140C.description: Rigorous treatment of multivariable differential calculus. Jacobians, Inverse and Implicit Function theorems.

MATH H140A.title: Honors Introduction to Graduate Analysis I
MATH H140A.description: Construction of the real number system, topology of the real line, concepts of continuity, differential and integral calculus, sequences and series of functions, equicontinuity, metric spaces, multivariable differential and integral calculus, implicit functions, curves and surfaces.
MATH H140A.prerequisites: (MATH 2E or MATH H2E) and (MATH 3A or MATH H3A) and MATH 13 and MATH 121A and MATH 140A. MATH 2E with a grade of A or better. MATH H2E with a grade of A or better. MATH 13 with a grade of A or better. MATH 121A with a grade of A or better. MATH 140A with a grade of A or better

MATH H140B.title: Honors Introduction to Graduate Analysis II
MATH H140B.description: Construction of the real number system, topology of the real line, concepts of continuity, differential and integral calculus, sequences and series of functions, equicontinuity, metric spaces, multivariable differential and integral calculus, implicit functions, curves and surfaces.
MATH H140B.prerequisites: MATH H140A. MATH H140A with a grade of C- or better

MATH H140C.title: Honors Introduction to Graduate Analysis III
MATH H140C.description: Construction of the real number system; topology of the real line; concepts of continuity, differential, and integral calculus; sequences and series of functions, equicontinuity, metric spaces, multivariable differential, and integral calculus; implicit functions, curves and surfaces.
MATH H140C.prerequisites: MATH H140B. MATH H140B with a grade of C- or better

MATH 141.title: Introduction to Topology
MATH 141.description: The elements of naive set theory and the basic properties of metric spaces. Introduction to topological properties.

MATH 147.title: Complex Analysis
MATH 147.description: Rigorous treatment of basic complex analysis: analytic functions, Cauchy integral theory and its consequences, power series, residue calculus, harmonic functions, conformal mapping. Students are expected to do proofs.

MATH 150.title: Introduction to Mathematical Logic
MATH 150.description: First order logic through the Completeness Theorem for predicate logic.
MATH 150.prerequisites: MATH 13 or (I&C SCI 6B and I&C SCI 6D). MATH 13 with a grade of C- or better. I&C SCI 6B with a grade of C- or better. I&C SCI 6D with a grade of C- or better

MATH 161.title: Modern Geometry
MATH 161.description: Euclidean Geometry; Hilbert's Axioms; Absolute Geometry; Hyperbolic Geometry; the Poincare Models; and Geometric Transformations.
MATH 161.prerequisites: MATH 13 or (I&C SCI 6B and I&C SCI 6D). MATH 13 with a grade of C- or better. I&C SCI 6B with a grade of C- or better. I&C SCI 6D with a grade of C- or better
MATH 161.restriction: : Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 162A.title: Introduction to Differential Geometry I
MATH 162A.description: Applications of advanced calculus and linear algebra to the geometry of curves and surfaces in space.

MATH 162B.title: Introduction to Differential Geometry II
MATH 162B.description: Applications of advanced calculus and linear algebra to the geometry of curves and surfaces in space.
MATH 162B.prerequisites: MATH 162A. MATH 162A with a grade of C- or better

MATH 173A.title: Introduction to Cryptology I
MATH 173A.description: Introduction to some of the mathematics used in the making and breaking of codes, with applications to classical ciphers and public key systems. Includes topics from number theory, probability, and abstract algebra.
MATH 173A.prerequisites: (MATH 2B or MATH 5B or MATH 7B or AP Calculus BC) and (MATH 3A or MATH H3A) and (MATH 13 or (I&C SCI 6B and I&C SCI 6D)). AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 4

MATH 173B.title: Introduction to Cryptology II
MATH 173B.description: Introduction to some of the mathematics used in the making and breaking of codes, with applications to classical ciphers and public key systems. The mathematics covered includes topics from number theory, probability, and abstract algebra.

MATH 175.title: Combinatorics
MATH 175.description: Introduction to combinatorics including basic counting principles, permutations, combinations, binomial coefficients, inclusion-exclusion, derangements, ordinary and exponential generating functions, recurrence relations, Catalan numbers, Stirling numbers, and partition numbers.
MATH 175.prerequisites: (MATH 2B or MATH 5B or MATH 7B or AP Calculus BC) and MATH 13. AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 4. MATH 13 with a grade of C- or better

MATH 176.title: Mathematics of Finance
MATH 176.description: After reviewing tools from probability, statistics, and elementary differential and partial differential equations, concepts such as hedging, arbitrage, Puts, Calls, the design of portfolios, the derivation and solution of the Blac-Scholes, and other equations are discussed.
MATH 176.restriction: : Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 178.title: Mathematical Machine Learning
MATH 178.description: Theoretical introduction to Mathematical Machine Learning. Mathematical foundations and coding implementations using Python libraries such as scikit-learn and Keras. Supervised and unsupervised learning; regression and classification; loss functions; overfitting and the bias-complexity tradeoff. Prominent algorithms in machine learning.

MATH 180A.title: Number Theory I
MATH 180A.description: Introduction to number theory and applications. Divisibility, prime numbers, factorization. Arithmetic functions. Congruences. Quadratic residue. Diophantine equations. Introduction to cryptography.
MATH 180A.prerequisites: (MATH 3A or MATH H3A) and MATH 13. MATH 13 with a grade of C- or better
MATH 180A.restriction: : Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 180B.title: Number Theory II
MATH 180B.description: Introduction to number theory and applications. Analytic number theory, character sums, finite fields, discrete logarithm, computational complexity. Introduction to coding theory. Other topics as time permits.
MATH 180B.restriction: : Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 184.title: History of Mathematics
MATH 184.description: Topics vary from year to year. Some possible topics: mathematics in ancient times; the development of modern analysis; the evolution of geometric ideas. Students will be assigned individual topics for term papers.
MATH 184.restriction: : Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 184L.title: History of Mathematics Lesson Lab
MATH 184L.description: Aspiring math teachers research, design, present, and peer review middle school or high school math lessons that draw from history of mathematics topics.

MATH 192.title: Studies in the Learning and Teaching of Secondary Mathematics
MATH 192.description: Focus is on historic and current mathematical concepts related to student learning and effective math pedagogy, with fieldwork in grades 6-14.

MATH 194.title: Problem Solving Seminar
MATH 194.description: Develops ability in analytical thinking and problem solving, using problems of the type found in the Mathematics Olympiad and the Putnam Mathematical Competition. Students taking the course in fall will prepare for and take the Putnam examination in December.

MATH 195W.title: Mathematical Writing
MATH 195W.description: Techniques of mathematical writing and communication. Covers effectively writing mathematical papers, creating effective presentations, and communicating mathematics in a variety of media. Focuses on utilizing LaTeX for typesetting mathematics.
MATH 195W.prerequisites: MATH 120A or MATH 121A or MATH 140A. MATH 120A with a grade of C- or better. MATH 121A with a grade of C- or better. MATH 140A with a grade of C- or better. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
MATH 195W.restriction: : Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 199A.title: Special Studies in Mathematics
MATH 199A.description: Supervised reading. For outstanding undergraduate Mathematics majors in supervised but independent reading or research of mathematical topics.

MATH 199B.title: Special Studies in Mathematics
MATH 199B.description: Supervised reading. For outstanding undergraduate Mathematics majors in supervised but independent reading or research of mathematical topics.

MATH 199C.title: Special Studies in Mathematics
MATH 199C.description: Supervised reading. For outstanding undergraduate Mathematics majors in supervised but independent reading or research of mathematical topics.

MATH 205A.title: Introduction to Graduate Analysis
MATH 205A.description: Construction of the real number system, topology of the real line, concepts of continuity, differential and integral calculus, sequences and series of functions, equicontinuity, metric spaces, multivariable differential and integral calculus, implicit functions, curves and surfaces.
MATH 205A.prerequisites: Recommended: MATH 2E and MATH 3A and MATH 13, or equivalent.

MATH 205B.title: Introduction to Graduate Analysis
MATH 205B.description: Construction of the real number system, topology of the real line, concepts of continuity, differential and integral calculus, sequences and series of functions, equicontinuity, metric spaces, multivariable differential and integral calculus, implicit functions, curves and surfaces.
MATH 205B.prerequisites: MATH 205A. MATH 205A with a grade of B- or better

MATH 205C.title: Introduction to Graduate Analysis
MATH 205C.description: Construction of the real number system, topology of the real line, concepts of continuity, differential and integral calculus, sequences and series of functions, equicontinuity, metric spaces, multivariable differential and integral calculus, implicit functions, curves and surfaces.
MATH 205C.prerequisites: MATH 205B. MATH 205B with a grade of B- or better

MATH 210A.title: Real Analysis
MATH 210A.description: Measure theory, Lebesgue integral, signed measures, Radon-Nikodym theorem, functions of bounded variation and absolutely continuous functions, classical Banach spaces, Lp spaces, integration on locally compact spaces and the Riesz-Markov theorem, measure and outer measure, product measure spaces.

MATH 210B.title: Real Analysis
MATH 210B.description: Measure theory, Lebesgue integral, signed measures, Radon-Nikodym theorem, functions of bounded variation and absolutely continuous functions, classical Banach spaces, Lp spaces, integration on locally compact spaces and the Riesz-Markov theorem, measure and outer measure, product measure spaces.
MATH 210B.prerequisites: MATH 210A. MATH 210A with a grade of B- or better

MATH 210C.title: Real Analysis
MATH 210C.description: Measure theory, Lebesgue integral, signed measures, Radon-Nikodym theorem, functions of bounded variation and absolutely continuous functions, classical Banach spaces, Lp spaces, integration on locally compact spaces and the Riesz-Markov theorem, measure and outer measure, product measure spaces.
MATH 210C.prerequisites: MATH 210B. MATH 210B with a grade of B- or better

MATH 211A.title: Topics in Analysis
MATH 211A.description: Studies in selected areas of Real Analysis, a continuation of MATH 210A-MATH 210B-MATH 210C. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

MATH 218A.title: Introduction to Manifolds and Geometry
MATH 218A.description: General topology and fundamental groups, covering space; Stokes theorem on manifolds, selected topics on abstract manifold theory.
MATH 218A.prerequisites: Recommended: MATH 140C and MATH 121B, or equivalent.

MATH 218B.title: Introduction to Manifolds and Geometry
MATH 218B.description: General topology and fundamental groups, covering space; Stokes theorem on manifolds, selected topics on abstract manifold theory.

MATH 218C.description: General topology and fundamental groups, covering space; Stokes theorem on manifolds, selected topics on abstract manifold theory.
MATH 218C.prerequisites: MATH 218B. MATH 218B with a grade of B- or better

MATH 220A.title: Analytic Function Theory
MATH 220A.description: Standard theorems about analytic functions. Harmonic functions. Normal families. Conformal mapping.

MATH 220B.title: Analytic Function Theory
MATH 220B.description: Standard theorems about analytic functions. Harmonic functions. Normal families. Conformal mapping.
MATH 220B.prerequisites: MATH 220A. MATH 220A with a grade of B- or better

MATH 220C.description: Standard theorems about analytic functions. Harmonic functions. Normal families. Conformal mapping.

MATH 222A.title: Several Complex Variables and Complex Geometry
MATH 222A.description: Several Complex variables, d-bar problems, mappings, Kaehler geometry, de Rham and Dolbeault Theorems, Chern Classes, Hodge Theorems, Calabi conjecture, Kahler-Einstein geometry, Monge-Ampere.
MATH 222A.prerequisites: MATH 220C. MATH 220C with a grade of B- or better

MATH 225A.title: Introduction to Numerical Analysis and Scientific Computing
MATH 225A.description: Introduction to fundamentals of numerical analysis from an advanced viewpoint. Error analysis, approximation of functions, nonlinear equations.
MATH 225A.prerequisites: Recommended: MATH 3D and MATH 105B and MATH 140A and MATH 121A and MATH 112A, or equivalent.

MATH 225B.title: Introduction to Numerical Analysis and Scientific Computing
MATH 225B.description: Introduction to fundamentals of numerical analysis from an advanced viewpoint. Numerical linear algebra, numerical solutions of differential equations; stability.
MATH 225B.prerequisites: MATH 225A. MATH 225A with a grade of B- or better

MATH 225C.title: Introduction to Numerical Analysis and Scientific Computing
MATH 225C.description: Introduction to fundamentals of numerical analysis from an advanced viewpoint. Numerical linear algebra, numerical solutions of differential equations; stability.
MATH 225C.prerequisites: Recommended: MATH 3D and MATH 105B and MATH 140A and MATH 121A and MATH 112A, or equivalent.

MATH 226A.title: Computational Differential Equations
MATH 226A.description: Finite difference and finite element methods. Quick treatment of functional and nonlinear analysis background: weak solution, Lp spaces, Sobolev spaces. Approximation theory. Fourier and Petrov-Galerkin methods; mesh generation. Elliptic, parabolic, hyperbolic cases in 226A-B-C, respectively.
MATH 226A.prerequisites: Recommended: MATH 3D and MATH 112A and (MATH 140B or MATH 105B), or equivalent.

MATH 226B.title: Computational Differential Equations
MATH 226B.description: Finite difference and finite element methods. Quick treatment of functional and nonlinear analysis background: weak solution, Lp spaces, Sobolev spaces. Approximation theory. Fourier and Petrov-Galerkin methods; mesh generation. Elliptic, parabolic, hyperbolic cases in 226A-B-C, respectively.
MATH 226B.prerequisites: Recommended: MATH 3D and MATH 112A and (MATH 140B or MATH 105B), or equivalent.

MATH 226C.title: Computational Differential Equations
MATH 226C.description: Finite difference and finite element methods. Quick treatment of functional and nonlinear analysis background: weak solution, Lp spaces, Sobolev spaces. Approximation theory. Fourier and Petrov-Galerkin methods; mesh generation. Elliptic, parabolic, hyperbolic cases in 226A-B-C, respectively.
MATH 226C.prerequisites: Recommended: MATH 3D and MATH 112A and (MATH 140B or MATH 105B), or equivalent.

MATH 227A.title: Mathematical and Computational Biology
MATH 227A.description: Analytical and numerical methods for dynamical systems, temporal-spatial dynamics, steady state, stability, stochasticity. Application to life sciences: genetics, tissue growth and patterning, cancers, ion channels gating, signaling networks, morphogen gradients. Analytical methods.
MATH 227A.prerequisites: Recommended: MATH 2A and MATH 2B and MATH 3A, or equivalent.

MATH 227B.title: Mathematical and Computational Biology
MATH 227B.description: Analytical and numerical methods for dynamical systems, temporal-spatial dynamics, steady state, stability, stochasticity. Application to life sciences: genetics, tissue growth and patterning, cancers, ion channels gating, signaling networks, morphogen gradients. Numerical simulations.
MATH 227B.prerequisites: MATH 227A. MATH 227A with a grade of B- or better

MATH 228.title: Topics in Applied Math Careers
MATH 228.description: Prepares students for math careers in industry.

MATH 230A.title: Algebra
MATH 230A.description: Elements of the theories of groups, rings, fields, modules. Galois theory. Modules over principal ideal domains. Artinian, Noetherian, and semisimple rings and modules.
MATH 230A.prerequisites: Recommended: MATH 120A and MATH 121A and MATH 120B, or equivalent.

MATH 232A.title: Algebraic Number Theory
MATH 232A.description: Algebraic integers, prime ideals, class groups, Dirichlet unit theorem, localization, completion, Cebotarev density theorem, L-functions, Gauss sums, diophantine equations, zeta functions over finite fields. Introduction to class field theory.
MATH 232A.prerequisites: MATH 230C. MATH 230C with a grade of B- or better

MATH 232B.title: Algebraic Number Theory
MATH 232B.description: Algebraic integers, prime ideals, class groups, Dirichlet unit theorem, localization, completion, Cebotarev density theorem, L-functions, Gauss sums, diophantine equations, zeta functions over finite fields. Introduction to class field theory.

MATH 233A.description: Basic commutative algebra and classical algebraic geometry. Algebraic varieties, morphisms, rational maps, blow ups. Theory of schemes, sheaves, divisors, cohomology. Algebraic curves and surfaces, Riemann-Roch theorem, Jacobians, classification of curves and surfaces.

MATH 240A.description: Riemannian manifolds, connections, curvature, and torsion. Submanifolds, mean curvature, Gauss curvature equation. MATH 260A.description: Normed linear spaces, Hilbert spaces, Banach spaces, Stone-Weierstrass Theorem, locally convex spaces, bounded operators on Banach and Hilbert spaces, the Gelfand-Neumark Theorem for commutative C*-algebras, the spectral theorem for bounded self-adjoint operators, unbounded operators on Hilbert spaces.
MATH 260A.prerequisites: MATH 210C and MATH 220C. MATH 210C with a grade of B- or better. MATH 220C with a grade of B- or better

MATH 260B.description: Normed linear spaces, Hilbert spaces, Banach spaces, Stone-Weierstrass Theorem, locally convex spaces, bounded operators on Banach and Hilbert spaces, the Gelfand-Neumark Theorem for commutative C*-algebras, the spectral theorem for bounded self-adjoint operators, unbounded operators on Hilbert spaces.

MATH 282A.title: Model Theory
MATH 282A.description: Languages, structures, compactness, and completeness. Model-theoretic constructions. Omitting types theorems. Morley's theorem. Ranks, forking. Model completeness. O-minimality. Applications to algebra.

MATH 282B.description: Languages, structures, compactness and completeness. Model-theoretic constructions. Omitting types theorems. Morley's theorem. Ranks, forking. Model completeness. O-minimality. Applications to algebra.

MATH 290A.title: Methods in Applied Mathematics
MATH 290A.description: Introduction to ODEs and dynamical systems: existence and uniqueness. Equilibria and periodic solutions. Bifurcation theory. Perturbation methods: approximate solution of differential equations. Multiple scales and WKB. Matched asymptotic. Calculus of variations: direct methods, Euler-Lagrange equation. Second variation and Legendre condition.

MATH 290B.description: Introduction to ODEs and dynamical systems: existence and uniqueness. Equilibria and periodic solutions. Bifurcation theory. Perturbation methods: approximate solution of differential equations. Multiple scales and WKB. Matched asymptotic. Calculus of variations: direct methods, Euler-Lagrange equation. Second variation and Legendre condition.

MATH 290C.description: Introduction to ODEs and dynamical systems: existence and uniqueness. Equilibria and periodic solutions. Bifurcation theory. Perturbation methods: approximate solution of differential equations. Multiple scales and WKB. Matched asymptotic. Calculus of variations: direct methods, Euler-Lagrange equation. Second variation and Legendre condition.
